awd_titl_txt: Single-, Few- and Many-Body Physics in Optical Superlattices
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use an ensemble of neutral atoms cooled to temperatures lower than anywhere else in the known Universe, held in a crystal formed by intersecting laser beams, superbly isolated from the outside world, and detected with highly sensitive imaging methods, to model and understand the properties of solid-state materials. The broad goal of this work is to promote the progress of science in two specific areas that are presently of high scientific and economic interest. First, experiments on these ultracold atomic gases will unravel central mysteries in materials science, specifically those pertaining to materials with strongly correlated electrons and frustrated magnetic interactions, both of which lead to novel phases of matter. These novel phases may enable advances in information storage, information processing, or high-temperature superconductivity. Second, this project advances capabilities in preparing and controlling complex quantum systems. These capabilities are expected to fuel the development of new quantum technologies. In fact, the graduate students and postdoctoral researchers conducting this work will gain valuable skills and be positioned to make significant contributions to the nascent quantum technologies sector, as well as in academic and other research positions. 

More specifically, this project focuses on the quantum properties of itinerant particles in two new non-primitive two-dimensional crystal structures: a trimerized Kagome lattice and a hexamerized honeycomb lattice. In the current experimental setup, the itinerant particles are rubidium atoms and the crystal structure is formed using a bichromatic optical lattice. In both lattice structures, strongly bonded multi-site plaquettes are coupled weakly to one another. In the limit of zero coupling between plaquettes, the lattices are composed of many fully isolated, few-site, few-particle quantum systems. Measurements will probe the single-body and few-body quantum states of these plaquettes, advancing our capabilities in quantum state engineering and realizing minimal representations of bosonic Laughlin states. In the regime where coupling between plaquettes is introduced, many-body physics emerges in a controlled manner. Measurements will be performed to reveal interesting orbital-magnetism states and characterize rapidly rotating lattice-trapped quantum gases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Materials science, whose central goal is to understand how macroscopic material properties arise from the microscopic makeup of a material, is fundamental to the advanced technologies that pervade our daily lives.  And one of the ways to advance materials science, and consequently our technologies, is to study model systems, whose microscopic makeup is simple, minimalist, and precisely known, and to compare the predictions for their behavior to their actual properties.

This project focused on constructing model systems for the study of materials using ultracold atomic gases and optical lattice potentials.  In this approach, the ultracold atoms serve as a proxy for electrons or other itinerant particles, and the optical lattice serves as a proxy for the ordered crystal in which these particles propagate.  Constructing a direct simulacrum (also known as a “quantum simulation”) of materials using ultracold atoms and optical lattices has the advantage that the model system is precisely characterized, that there is great flexibility in tuning the model system to see how microscopic properties of materials influence their macroscopic behavior, and that we can apply a broad suite of measurement techniques to probe these model systems.

Specifically, this project focused on two dimensional optical superlattices, and resulted in three major outcomes, each described in prominent peer-reviewed publications.  The first outcome was the first quantum simulation of the trimerized kagome lattice geometry.  This work is relevant to our efforts to understand the unusual properties of geometrically frustrated materials, ones in which constraints on either motion or magnetism at different locations in the crystal compete with one another.  The trimerized (or “breathing”) kagome lattice is often considered in theoretical attempts to understand geometric frustration from a well understood starting point.  Our study revealed some interesting properties of this lattice geometry – asymmetries in the spatial coherence of strongly interacting particles propagating in this lattice – and also set the stage for future studies of plaquette lattices.

A second major outcome was the observation of band-structure renormalization in an optical kagome lattice.  The band structure of a material, which characterizes the motion of non-interacting particles in a crystalline potential, is the standard starting point for understanding materials properties.  In some instances, however, this non-interacting band structure does a poor job at describing a real material in which the itinerant particles interact with one another.  The modification of band structure owing to the effects of interactions is known as band-structure renormalization.  In our work, we studied the motion of thousands of atoms that were all excited into the same state within the band structure of the kagome lattice.  By measuring the velocity distribution of the gas upon suddenly switching off the optical lattice, we measured the group velocity, which is a property derived directly from band structure.  Whereas geometric frustration causes the group velocity in a particular band of the kagome lattice to go to zero, we measured instead the group velocity in this band to be clearly non-zero.  By tuning parameters of our quantum simulator, and then matching with theoretical calculations, we explained our findings as an effect of band structure renormalization.  This finding is important as we continue to study geometrically frustrated materials through quantum simulation.

A third major outcome was the development of a new method for measuring sharp singularities in the band structure of crystals.  These sharp singularities, where two or more bands within the band structure have the same energy and quasi-momentum, are known to have profound implications to the properties of materials, exemplified by the physics of graphene.  We found a new method, based on parallel transport, which allows these singularities to be identified and completely characterized.  Using our new ability to vary our optical lattices in real time and with tight experimental control, we performed experiments in which a quantum gas of atoms was slowly transported into and out of singular points in band structure; specifically, we examined linear and quadratic band touching points within the band structure of the honeycomb lattice.  By measuring the redistribution of atoms between bands after this transport, we measured geometric properties of the band-structure singularities (the non-Abelian Berry connection).  This work will change how people think about band structure singularities in materials and about parallel transport.   In the long run, our improved understanding of such geometric singularities will improve our understanding of materials.

This work was conducted by a capable team of undergraduate students, graduate students, visiting students, and postdoctoral researchers, together with the principal investigator, at a major public university.  This research thereby provided invaluable scientific training to a number of young scientists who are now contributing through their work in industry and academia.
